projectTitle: The Attention Mechanism: Automated Lesson Development
subtitle: Felix's Challenge: One-Shot Assignment Completion Through Agentic Orchestration

epicSequence.description: Product Manager configured with orchestration capabilities
Environment setup, notebook scaffolding, module stubs
Core attention mechanism implementation across 4 sections

architecturalDecisions.rationale: Product Manager orchestrates Team Leads who delegate to Specialists
architecturalDecisions.outcome: Clear separation of concerns and manageable complexity

architecturalDecisions.rationale: Enable isolated agent instances to share state via .epic[n]_complete.json
architecturalDecisions.outcome: Seamless knowledge transfer between epics without shared memory

architecturalDecisions.rationale: True automation without human intervention during epic execution
Dynamic specialist creation reduces upfront prompt engineering
architecturalDecisions.outcome: Flexible agent spawning based on epic-specific needs

architecturalDecisions.rationale: Prevent clutter and version conflicts during development
architecturalDecisions.outcome: Single comprehensive documentation pass on stable codebase

architecturalDecisions.rationale: Intelligent code comparison instead of brittle rule-based grading

keyMilestones.significance: Product Manager configured with orchestration patterns, hooks, and logging
Notebook structure, environment setup, and module stubs ready for implementation
All 4 attention mechanism sections implemented with educational clarity
Abstract tensor operations made visible through matplotlib visualizations
Student implementations compared to production transformers (distilgpt2)
Web interface and comprehensive documentation complete user experience
Content validation and student simulation confirm system ready

technicalAchievements: Cross-platform virtual environment setup with pinned dependencies
Parallel notebook architecture: student version (lesson.ipynb) and reference (complete_lesson.ipynb)
Single-head attention implementation with consistent tensor shapes throughout
Educational visualizations with batch dimension handling [1, 6, 6] → [6, 6]
Dual LLM provider system: Ollama local, OpenAI fallback
Intelligent evaluation comparing student code against reference implementation
Production model integration with distilgpt2 caching for offline use
Accessible web interface (WCAG 2.1 AA) with professional dark theme
Six comprehensive documentation files covering all user needs
Systematic validation through epic-specific validators and student simulation

challengesOvercome.solution: Comprehensive file operation logging via hooks for post-mortem analysis
Completion file protocol with structured JSON handoffs
Tiered model strategy: Opus for PM, Sonnet for team-leads, cheaper models for specialists
Documented shapes in completion files, validated at each epic
Careful squeezing operations [1, 6, 6] → [6, 6] with shape validation
Dual provider system with automatic fallback and structured prompts
Focus on architectural similarity rather than exact dimension matching

challengesOvercome.challenge: UX issues missed by technical validation
challengesOvercome.solution: Student simulation agent experiencing system as learner would

agentContributions.productManager: Orchestrated entire workflow, spawned team-leads, managed completion protocol, performed final validation and fixes
agentContributions.teamLeads: Read completion files, analyzed epic requirements, consulted meta-agent, delegated to specialists, compiled handoff data

specialists.environmentSetup: Cross-platform virtual environment and dependency management
specialists.pytorchImplementation: Core attention mechanism with correct tensor operations
specialists.educationalContent: Theory explanations connecting mathematics to code
specialists.visualization: Matplotlib plots making attention patterns visible
specialists.notebookIntegration: Ensuring visualizations work inline in Jupyter
specialists.evaluation: LLM-based code comparison and feedback generation
specialists.modelComparison: Comparing student implementations to production transformers
specialists.webInterface: Professional HTML interface with dark theme and accessibility

agentContributions.studentSimulation: Authentic learner perspective revealing UX issues

lessonsLearned: Meta-agent pattern is crucial for dynamic specialist creation
Completion file protocol enables stateless agent coordination
Comprehensive logging is essential for debugging headless sessions
Student simulation catches UX issues technical validation misses
Deferring documentation prevents version conflicts and clutter
LLM-based evaluation provides superior educational feedback vs rules
Three-tier hierarchy (PM → Team Lead → Specialist) manages complexity well
Tiered model strategy (Opus/Sonnet/cheaper) balances cost and capability

projectOutcome.felixAssessment: I'm at the stage where I'm happy even if it didn't make it all the way. Tests, validation and simulations have given me the impression I'm 99% of the way there - That's more than I thought was possible to be honest.
projectOutcome.challengeResponse: One-shot assignment completion achieved through automated agent orchestration

deliverables.educationalValue: Complete interactive lesson on transformer attention mechanisms

learningObjectives: Apply softmax normalization to attention scores
Compute value aggregation with attention weights
systemFeatures: Interactive Jupyter notebooks with 4 implementation sections
